DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reports Pentagon Considering Big Troop Cuts In Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Defense planners are suggesting a possible two-thirds reduction in U.S. Army forces in South Korea as part of proposed drastic cuts in U.S. troop strength in the Pacific, The Washington Post reported today. The options for troop cuts were presented to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in a meeting Monday at the Pentagon, the Post reported, citing unidentified sources. No decisions have been made on the proposals, the newspaper said. Maj. David Super, a spokesman for the Pentagon, said he knew nothing about the meeting reported by the newspaper. Overall in the Pacific, the maximum amount of cuts contemplated in the Pentagon briefing paper given to Cheney would mean a reduction of 80,000 people from the Army and Air Force by the end of the 1994 fiscal year for a savings of $3.6 billion, the newspaper reported. Currently the Army has 32,052 people stationed in South Korea and options presented to Cheney would cut that to a 5,200-person brigade and another 6,550 in support, the newspaper said.
